Germany Steps Up Bonus Curbs at Commerzbank, Hypo Real Estate

October 04, 2010, 6:01 AM EDT

More From Businessweek

  • EU Needs Powers to Ban Financial Products, ESMA’s Maijoor Says
  • Siemens Delays Osram Lighting Unit IPO as Markets Retreat
  • Deposit Flight at European Banks Means Risk Piling Up at ECB
  • Barroso Vows Euro-Bond Options, Countering German Concerns
  • Italy Parliament Set for Final Confidence Vote on Austerity

Story Tools

  • add to Business Exchange
  • E-mail
  • Print

By Rainer Buergin and Brian Parkin

Oct. 4 (Bloomberg) -- German Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government plans to tighten curbs on bonuses for staff at banks including Commerzbank AG and Hypo Real Estate Holding AG that it bailed out during the financial crisis.

The government is examining ways to cap variable compensation for the highest-paid managers below executive-board level, a move that would involve changing existing employment contracts, Finance Ministry spokesman Michael Offer said in an e-mailed statement.

“State aid is nothing other than taxpayers’ money,” Leo Dautzenberg, finance spokesman for Merkel’s Christian Democratic Union, said today in an interview. “Legally, it’s all well and good for bank executives to make and receive pay commensurate with their performance. But when a bank is dependent on state aid, that has to be reflected in the rewards.”

Merkel, whose coalition trails the opposition in polls, is stepping up her efforts to target bankers’ pay amid public outrage over a widening gap between rich and poor. While Hypo Real Estate awarded staff 25 million euros ($34 million) in bonuses last year, the government said Sept. 27 that long-term welfare recipients will get an extra monthly allowance of 5 euros.

Germany enacted caps in 2008 on bonuses of 500,000 euros for executive-board members at institutions that received government funds. A clause in the law governing the Soffin bank- rescue fund obliges those banks to pay managers an amount that’s “adequate” to their performance.

Soffin Guarantees

Merkel’s government is closing its 480 billion-euro Soffin fund to new applicants at the end of the year. Set up in 2008 to keep Germany’s financial system afloat during the crisis, Soffin guaranteed 174.5 billion euros in liabilities and injected 29.3 billion euros in cash into Commerzbank, Hypo Real Estate, Aareal Bank AG and WestLB AG as of Sept. 30, it said on its Web site.

Sixty-eight managers at the four banks earn more than 500,000 euros per year, Der Spiegel magazine reported in this week’s edition, citing an internal document drawn up by the Soffin bank-rescue fund. Offer denied that the government wants to cap pay at 500,000 euros.

“Banks that have received an equity injection from the tax payer also have to accept the government’s assessment of what adequate compensation is,” Michael Meister, finance spokesman in parliament for Merkel’s CDU, said today in an e-mailed statement. “While this is already true for executive board members, the pay rules imposed by the government must be applied to all employees.”

The coalition aims to reach an agreement with the Justice Ministry by Oct. 6 on the legal procedures needed to change banking staff contracts to incorporate the pay caps, Dautzenberg said. That same day, the Finance Committee is due to hold an open hearing on the so-called Bank Restructuring Bill now going through parliament which will incorporate the legislation.

“We’re aiming to use the current legislative process to come to reasonable, but also legally compliant solutions that are transparent, sustainable and performance related,” the Finance Ministry’s Offer said.

--Editors: Alan Crawford, James Hertling

To contact the reporters on this story: Rainer Buergin in Berlin at rbuergin1@bloomberg.net; Brian Parkin in Berlin at bparkin@bloomberg.net
